newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore MAS sees 1996 inflation under 2 pct.
newsitem.headline: Singapore MAS sees 1996 inflation under 2 pct.

text.p: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said on Wednesday Singapore's overall inflation was expected to be below 2.0 percent for all of 1996 compared to 1.7 percent in 1995.
The MAS said in its annual report that inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, was expected to be under control for the rest 1996.
It said foreign inflationary pressures would be subdued, as growth in the industrial and regional economies slackened.
The MAS, Singapore's de facto central bank, said an increase in the intake of foreign workers moderated wage growth in 1995.
But in the medium-term, the Singapore economy would be susceptible to periodic bouts of overheating in the labour market, it said.
The central bank said it would remain vigilant against a resurgence of inflationary pressures in conducting Singapore's exchange rate policy.
